title: Friction Quiz
description: MCQs on static, kinetic, limiting friction, angle of friction, rolling friction, and applications.

questions.question: A block of mass 10 kg rests on a horizontal floor. The coefficient of static friction is 0.4. What is the maximum horizontal force that can be applied before the block just starts moving? (g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Maximum static friction = μs × N = 0.4 × (10 × 10) = 40 N.

questions.question: If the coefficient of kinetic friction is 0.3 for the same 10 kg block, what is the frictional force while sliding?
If μ = 0.5, then the angle of friction (φ) is:
questions.explanation: tan φ = μ → φ = arctan(0.5) ≈ 26.57°. (Option closest: 27°).

questions.question: A block just begins to slide down a rough inclined plane when the inclination is 30°. The coefficient of static friction between block and plane is:
questions.explanation: At limiting equilibrium, tan θ = μs → μs = tan 30° = 0.577.

questions.question: A uniform ladder of length 6 m rests against a smooth vertical wall making an angle of 60° with the horizontal. If the coefficient of friction between ladder and ground is μ, the minimum μ required for equilibrium is:
questions.explanation: Using equilibrium equations for ladder, μmin = 1 / (√3) ≈ 0.288.

questions.question: A rope is wound over a rough pulley through an angle of π radians (180°). The coefficient of friction is 0.25. If the tension on the tight side is 200 N, the slack side tension is:
A sphere of radius 0.2 m and weight 50 N experiences rolling resistance with K = 2 × 10⁻³ m. The rolling friction force is:
Which of the following is always true?
questions.explanation: Kinetic friction is always less than static friction for the same pair of surfaces.
